headline: CNN News Central
subHeadline: Emergency Hearing Begins In Georgia Election Interference Case Against Trump; Star Witness Expected To Testify in Effort To Disqualify Fulton County D.A. Aired 2-2:30p ET

utterances.speaker: BRIANNA KEILAR, CNN HOST
utterances.sentences: Hi there, I'm Brianna Keiler alongside Boris Sanchez here in Washington. And in minutes, an emergency hearing is going to begin that could disrupt, might even upend, the Georgia election interference case against former President Trump and more than a dozen other co-defendants. A star witness for them is expected to take the stand in the attempt to disqualify Fulton County D.A. Fani Willis and remove her from the case. Terrence Bradley is the former divorce attorney for Nathan Wade, a prosecutor who had a romantic relationship with Willis.

utterances.speaker: BORIS SANCHEZ, CNN HOST
utterances.sentences: And that involvement is the basis for defense attorney's efforts to remove Willis and Wade from the case. The defense says that Bradley could show the court that prosecutors have not been honest about their romance, and specifically when it started. As we wait for the hearing to begin, CNN's Nick Valencia and Zach Cohen are here to fill in the details. Nick, you are outside the courthouse. What can you tell us about what we expecting to see during this hearing?

utterances.speaker: NICK VALENCIA, CNN CORRESPONDENT
utterances.sentences: Yeah, hey there, Boris and Brianna. This is all going to focus and center around what Terrence Bradley knows about the romantic relationship between Fani Willis and Nathan Wade. The judge wants to know everything that Terrence Bradley knows about when this relationship started and any other details that he can provide. And you remember Ashley Merchant, she's the defense attorney that says that Bradley can prove that Fani Willis and Nathan Wade weren't being fully truthful about when their relationship began.So what's going to happen? What's really interesting about this all is that this allegation started as a claim that Fani Willis may have financially benefited from hiring Nathan Wade as the lead prosecutor in this case, but it's now morphed into whether or not Fani Willis and Nathan Wade were telling the truth on the stand when they testified just a couple of weeks ago. Guys.

utterances.speaker: SANCHEZ
utterances.sentences: Zach Cohen, let's go to you now. Let's take a few steps back, Zach. Walk us through what we learned that led up to this hearing.

utterances.speaker: ZACHARY COHEN, CNN NATIONAL SECUIRTY REPORTER
utterances.sentences: Yeah, Boris and Brianna, you'll remember that up until about a month ago, we were all talking about Donald Trump and when he might have to stand trial in Georgia as part of this election subversion case. But that changed in January when one of his co-defendants, Mike Roman, a former campaign official, filed this motion first surfacing these allegations that Fani Willis and Nathan Wade, our top prosecutor, were engaged in this alleged improper romantic relationship.And look, the judge since then has laid out the threshold for disqualification. He has said that defense attorneys have to prove that Willis benefited financially from that relationship. But he also laid out two other questions that he sought to answer through what we now have three days of hearings. One was, was the relationship romantic? And two, when did that relationship start? Willis and Wade have both acknowledged that, yes, the relationship was romantic, but we were still kind of trying to work through the answer to that second question. When did it start? That is the focus still to this day of the hearing that we're going to hear Nathan Wade testify in. We've already heard Fani Willis, though, take the stand. Remember earlier this month she gave an unprompted and unpredicted testimony. Take a listen to what she said when she took the stand earlier this month. (BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: FANI WILLIS, DISTRICT ATTORNEY OF FULTON COUNTY
utterances.sentences: You've been intrusive into people's personal lives. You're confused. You think I'm on trial. These people are on trial for trying to steal an election in 2020. I'm not on trial no matter how hard you try to put me on trial.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: COHEN
utterances.sentences: So the conversation has clearly shifted from Trump to Willis. And again, we're entering now our third day of evidentiary hearings over this issue of whether or not Fonny Willis will be removed from the case or whether the case could continue on as it was before the allegations first surfaced.

utterances.speaker: KEILAR
utterances.sentences: All right, Zach, and here we are. Court has reconvened here. We see Judge Scott McAfee there on the bench. I want to bring in Laura Coates to talk a little bit about what we're seeing and what we're expecting here today.

utterances.speaker: SANCHEZ
utterances.sentences: A big question in this case, obviously, and the implications for the former president are huge. We're listening in right now to the conversation between Judge McAfee and the lawyers in the room. And right now, at this point, it's been largely procedural. We are expecting Terrence Bradley to appear via Zoom shortly. We also have with us Paula Reid and Gloria Borger. Paula, there is a specific piece of evidence that the defense is going to try to introduce here, and it has to do with cell phone pings related to Nathan Wade and the proximity that he was in to D.A. Willis before their relationship reportedly started.

utterances.speaker: PAULA REID, CNN CHIEF LEGAL AFFAIRS CORRESPONDENT
utterances.sentences: That's exactly right. The so-called heat map that shows that they were in the same location for a certain period of time. Now, this kind of data is not conclusive to some of the key issues in this case, which is, did they have a relationship? They've acknowledged that publicly, but at what time did that begin? And they're trying to insinuate that because there was so much contact, because there was so much proximity, that that must suggest that perhaps this relationship began sooner than what they've said.So, if they have data, again, it's not conclusive. I mean, it certainly raises questions. The Trump team released it to much fanfare in recent days. But, yeah, it's not conclusive. But they're going to bring it up, and we'll see what the judge does with it.

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: The point is to make it as messy as possible, right?

utterances.speaker: KEILAR
utterances.sentences: Yeah, let's take a moment and listen in here, because they're going over this issue of privileges, says the judge, Scott McAfee.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: JUDGE SCOTT MCAFEE, FULTON COUNTY SUPERIOR COURT
utterances.sentences: In my mind, it's that topic only. I think if there's anything else we've already covered, I'm not here to do it again. So, with that, is there anything else we need to cover before kicking that off?

utterances.speaker: ASHLEIGH MERCHANT, ATTORNEY
utterances.sentences: Just, Mr. Wade, he's still a potential witness. So, he's still, excuse me, we'll continue.

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: Mr. (inaudible). UNKNOWNconcluded his testimony the last year. So, unless he's been re- subpoenaed, and I have no knowledge of that. He has every right to be present.

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: Sure. I think, procedurally, that would be accurate. And so, at this point, I don't see a means where he would need to be recalled. And, but if it is, then that is something you can take up. All right. Mr. Bradley threw his attorney to inform me that he would be here today in person. I don't see him in the gallery. Do we know if he's out in the hallway?MERCHANT (?): I see the attorney.

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: Okay. All right. If we could call for Mr. Bradley.

utterances.speaker: UNKNOWN
utterances.sentences: Judge, would it be permissible to sit in the jury's office?

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: That's fine.

utterances.speaker: UNKNOWN
utterances.sentences: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: All right, Mr. Bradley. Deputy Scott will swear you in again.(inaudible) TERRENCE BRADLEY, SPECIAL PROSECUTOR NATHAN WADE'S FORMER LAW PARTNER: I do. Terrence Bradley, T-E-R-R-E-N-C-E Bradley, B-R-E-D-L-E-Y.

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: All right, Ms. Merchant.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: Thank you, Judge. Good afternoon, Mr. Bradley.

utterances.speaker: BRADLEY
utterances.sentences: Good afternoon.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: I'm sorry, under these circumstances, I'm going to just go straight to where we left off before. Fonny Willis and Nathan Wade were in a romantic relationship, correct?

utterances.speaker: BRADLEY
utterances.sentences: Correct.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: And it began at the time that they were both municipal court judges, correct?

utterances.speaker: UNKNOWN
utterances.sentences: Objection, Your Honor, based on privilege.

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: Okay, overruled.

utterances.speaker: BRALEY
utterances.sentences: I do not have knowledge of its starting or when it started.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: Terrence, you told me that it started when they were both municipal court judges, though, correct?

utterances.speaker: BRADLEY
utterances.sentences: That is incorrect.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: You never confirmed in writing that it was instead of magistrate court, it was in municipal court when they started dating?

utterances.speaker: BRADLEY
utterances.sentences: If you're speaking of the text message, you can go to that text message and you can read that text message and I will explain the text message to you. But you and I did not have a conversation when it started. You asked a compound question of magistrate court versus, I mean, you said it was magistrate court, municipal, I mean, you said magistrate court conference, I'm sorry. And then you asked another question. I said no, municipal court, nothing else.

utterances.speaker: UNKNOWN
utterances.sentences: And I'm gonna object, this was covered in the previous hearing where Mr. Bradley said he had no personal knowledge of the exact text that Ms. Merchant is speaking of and actually used in an attempt to refresh his recollection. And he explained exactly what he's explaining before the court. So, this is repetitive and unnecessary. And I would object to past answered and relevance at the same time.

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: All right, perhaps we'll get there. But I think first, Ms. Merchant has the right to draw his attention to the exact, potentially inconsistent statement.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: Thank you, Judge. May I approach him?

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: It's overruled.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: This is the text I gave you.MCAFEE (?): And for purposes of the record, I believe Ms. Merchant, you tendered, was it the entire text chain as an exhibit?

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: I only tendered a few of the texts, but I did give the state their copy, their copy. They're courtesy copies last time of the exhibit.

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: Was this one tendered?

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: This one was not tendered.

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: All right.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: And I'm happy to tender it.

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: We'll just take it as it comes, whatever you

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: We're at, I think we're at 39. I will wait to mark it, but I think we're at 39. May I approach Judge?

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: You may.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: All right. So, Terrence, do you remember telling me that it started when she left the DA's office and was a judge in South Holton? BRADLEY

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: You don't recall texting this?

utterances.speaker: BRADLEY
utterances.sentences: I look back at my text messages through that we've had. I see that message, but I do not recall that. No, ma'am.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: And when I asked you if you thought it started before she hired him and you responded, absolutely.

utterances.speaker: UNKNOWN
utterances.sentences: Your Honor, I'm going to object as to the source of the information that Mr. Bradley allegedly gathered this from. There's been absolutely no foundation based on the arguments of the last hearing that a lot of this is based on gossip, innuendo, assumption and privileged information. And at this point, Ms. Merchant has not provided a foundation as to how Mr. Bradley would have any information that she keeps referring to.

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: All right, I think that's, --  go ahead, Ms. Merchant.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: I didn't ask him about the source of the information and under Rule 621, I can impeach him with any inconsistent facts. This is an inconsistent fact. I can impeach him with any contrary facts.

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: Why would it be a relevant impeachment if he actually has no personal knowledge of this?

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: If he doesn't.

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: Sure, so I think you have to lay that foundation then, so that'll be sustained.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: Okay. Do you remember telling me that it began?

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: Well, that doesn't address the issue.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: No, I was just asking if you remember telling me as opposed to the text.

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: Sure.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: Do you remember telling me that it began?

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: Well, no, and then you're going into the substance of it, which we haven't determined whether he actually knows or how he knows.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: You told me, in fact, you corrected me when I said Magistrate Court. You corrected me and said it was Municipal Court. Do you remember that?

utterances.speaker: UNKNOWN
utterances.sentences: Same objection, Your Honor.

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: This is the exact same issue, right?

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: Well, I'm asking if he remembers that. He hasn't answered that question yet.

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: Right, but the relevance of whether he remembers it isn't established until we know how he remembers it or why he knows it, if that makes sense. I guess not. Sorry.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: I'm sorry. I'm just asking if he told me that, so I wasn't asking how he knew that. I wasn't asking the source of that knowledge. I was asking if he told me that.

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: Right. Sure.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: That's it.

utterances.speaker: UNKNOWN
utterances.sentences: But that's the point. It's how he knows it. The source of his knowledge is hearsay because it's gossip and innuendo, which is what was indicated at the last hearing.

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: Well, it may not be hearsay. It may not be gossip. We haven't really gotten there yet. We don't know how he knows what apparently he's telling her, and I think we need to figure that out before we can go any further.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: Yes. And if the source of the information is a witness who found it, then we can't tell him anything. So when did the relationship start?

utterances.speaker: BRADLEY
utterances.sentences: I cannot answer that.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: When was your first knowledge of the relationship?

utterances.speaker: UNKNOWN
utterances.sentences: Your Honor. He's already answered that question multiple times today. He said he had no idea the timeline or when it occurred. That was one of the first questions that this person asked.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: I didn't ask when. I asked his first knowledge. He testified he has knowledge that they had a relationship. I asked him when he first got knowledge of that.

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: Okay. So, the question is, when did you first get knowledge? I think -- okay, we can start there.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: That was the question.

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: All right.

utterances.speaker: BRADLEY
utterances.sentences: I've said over again that I was not, I didn't have any personal information where I could personally say when it started. I've said that time and time again so I don't, I don't know when the relationship started.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: And that wasn't my question. So, my question is when did you first gain knowledge? I didn't ask the source of the knowledge, didn't ask you to comment on the validity of the knowledge. I asked when you first had knowledge.

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: We'll get to the how my Albani (ph), so I'll note the objection overrule it, you can answer that just for the record.

utterances.speaker: UNKNOWN
utterances.sentences: Just for the record, I appreciate your Honor,  but he said he has no personal knowledge so it's clear he had to gain the knowledge not from hearsay.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: He could have gained it from his weight.

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: Well, I mean, most of us learn things from hearsay, the question of whether it's admissible right and that's what we got to get to.

utterances.speaker: BRADLEY
utterances.sentences: I apologize.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: Right, when did you first get knowledge? I'm not qualifying what type of knowledge, I'm just asking when you first knew about the relationship.

utterances.speaker: BRADLEY
utterances.sentences: I don't know how to answer that. I mean, so I can't give you a date, if you're asking for a date. If you're asking me how did I get the knowledge, it would have come directly from a client.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: BRADLEY
utterances.sentences: So, help me understand.

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: I think you say you can't answer that question. You don't know the date, so that's the answer to the question.

utterances.speaker: BRADLEY
utterances.sentences: But I said that five minutes ago.

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: We have to make it clear. Yes, sir, next question is Merchant.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: But you don't know the specific date.

utterances.speaker: BRADLEY
utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: Do you know if it can we narrow down the timeline? Was it, --  did you gain knowledge in 2019 of this relationship beginning?

utterances.speaker: UNKNOWN
utterances.sentences: I'm going to object to this line of questioning as he said he does not know when he gained.

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: All right.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: He doesn't know the specific date.

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: Sorry Ms Merchant. I'm overruling that. I think we can try to see if he can narrow it down based on goal posts.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: Thank you. Bradleyanything that I'm, --  there wasn't a specific date. There wasn't a football game. There wasn't something that I can attribute to him telling me whatever. And so, you're asking for a date, you're asking for a year. It's still a date. And at this time I am telling you that I do not have the date.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: Let's try this then. So you received a contract from Miss Willis, um, January 2021, correct? BRADLEY

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: Okay.

utterances.speaker: BRADLEY
utterances.sentences: -- I think, I think -- it was from the exhibits, I think it was '21. Yes.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: And I don't want to belabor the point. When you were here before(CROSSTALK)

utterances.speaker: BRADLEY
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: -- if those documents that you looked at last time

utterances.speaker: BRADLEY
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: January 2022, that's okay,

utterances.speaker: BRADLEY
utterances.sentences: Twenty-one.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: I'm sorry, '21. You're right.

utterances.speaker: BRADLEY
utterances.sentences: And it was, I think, renewed in '22.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: It was. Yes. So, the contract date was that we have in the record is January 25th, 2022. So using that date, at that point, had they begun their romantic relationship?

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: January 25th, 2022, 2021. I'm sorry, when you got your first contract.

utterances.speaker: BRADLEY
utterances.sentences: I don't recall.  I don't recall any specific  dates.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: You remember when you got that contract though, correct?

utterances.speaker: BRADLEY
utterances.sentences: I remember about the contract, yes.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: And you told us last week or, I guess it was the week before now, you told us that Mr. Wade brought you that contract, essentially told you about that contract.

utterances.speaker: BRADLEY
utterances.sentences: That is correct.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: So Miss Willis is not the one that brought that contract to you directly, it was Mr. Wade?

utterances.speaker: BRADLEY
utterances.sentences: That is correct.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: At that point in time, they were already engaged in a relationship though.

utterances.speaker: UNKNOWN
utterances.sentences: I'm going to object, --(CROSSTALK)

utterances.speaker: BRADLEY
utterances.sentences: I can't say that

utterances.speaker: UNKNOWN
utterances.sentences: -- the authorization of what Mr. Bradley just said. He just said he does not remember, there's nothing specific, --(CROSSTALK)

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: he doesn't remember the exact date. I think the question now is to reference it or tie it to maybe some other event that he might remember.

utterances.speaker: UNKNOWN
utterances.sentences: I agree with your honor, she asked that specific question, he said he does not remember any specific dates after signing the contract, that's exactly what he just said.

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: Sure.

utterances.speaker: UNKNOWN
utterances.sentences: This is asked and  answered.

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: I know and we're getting to the end of it. So, Miss Merchant, you don't have much more to pull on here, but he answered that last question, so what's your next one?

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: And Judge, I didn't hear the answer if they were in a relationship January 25th, 2021.

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: Do you recall the question?

utterances.speaker: BRADLEY
utterances.sentences: I recall the question and I can't tell you actually whether or not they were in a relationship at the time. You asked me about him bringing me a contract. I said he did bring me a contract and that is accurate.

utterances.speaker: BRADLEY
utterances.sentences: I had very little contact with Miss Willis. Um, I knew her, um, through my business of coming down to Fulton. If that's what you're asking, yes.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: Yyou knew her through the business, um. So, had you had met her prior to your contract? UNKNOWN

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: Sure.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: Judge, he doesn't remember much of anything right now, and so I'm trying to create a timeline to hopefully piece this together.

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: All right, well, I'm not seeing really the likelihood that that's going to have any success. I'll let you ask a few more questions, but if he doesn't have a date then I don't know that you're going to be able to create one today.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: Okay, thank you. So the time that you had this contract from January 2021 until January 2022, did you come in and out of the D.A.'s office?

utterances.speaker: BRADLEY
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: Okay, and so were you able to witness Mr. Wade and Miss Willis interact during that time?

utterances.speaker: UNKNOWN
utterances.sentences: I'm going to object; this has been asked and answered. It was addressed at the last hearing about Mr. Bradley's access to and from a specific room to pick up files, and Mr. Bradley said that he rarely saw them together. But this was(CROSSTALK)

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: I think, the only avenue that was closed at the last hearing was his personal knowledge, potentially through -- well, actually no, if he testified is that he had no personal knowledge, it's knowledge that conveyed to him that was cut off at the last hearing. That's really the only thing we hadn't been able to explore unless you correct me if I'm wrong.(CROSSTALK)

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: Knowledge that was conveyed to him(CROSSTALK)

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: --  by somebody else that he claimed at the time was privileged. I found that it's not; that's what we're here to explore.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: Okay, do you remember telling me that not many people knew where they met?

utterances.speaker: UNKNOWN
utterances.sentences: I'm going to object to relevance as to his personal knowledge, which is what 602 requires.

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: Yeah, we're back to the same point, Miss Merchant.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: His personal knowledge is what I'm asking him, what he told me. But he hasn't yet told you how he knows that, and so if unless he -- you can establish why he should be testifying on this at all, then there's relevance.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: And I don't know what how he knows that(CROSSTALK)

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: Well then ask him.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: That would be the next question.(CROSSTALK)

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: Then ask him how he knows it.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: I  first have to establish that he said that.

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: No, you don't, you could go the other way around.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: When you told me that it started when you left, when she left the office and was a judge in South Fulton, where did you gain that knowledge from?

utterances.speaker: UNKNOWN
utterances.sentences: Oh, I'm gonna object because his testimony a few minutes ago is that he did not recall making that statement.

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: All right, I'll overrule that, Mr. Bradley, answer the question if you can.

utterances.speaker: BRADLEY
utterances.sentences: Repeat the question.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: When you told me that their relationship started when she left the D.A.'s office and was a judge in South Fulton, where did you obtain that knowledge from?

utterances.speaker: BRADLEY
utterances.sentences: I was speculating. I  didn't have a -- no one told me, I was speculating.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: No one told you that?

utterances.speaker: BRADLEY
utterances.sentences: No one told me that.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: You were speculating based on things that had been told to you or things you had observed?

utterances.speaker: UNKNOWN
utterances.sentences: So, I'm going to object as to the nature of  this line of questioning because the witness has made it clear he was speculating as to how or what he knew, and if it's speculation, it's inadmissible before the court.

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: All right, but the motivations for his reason for speculating would be admissible, so I'll overrule that.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: Thank you Judge. Was this speculation when you told me that? Was that based on things that had been told to you and things that you have witnessed.

utterances.speaker: BRADLEY
utterances.sentences: I never witnessed anything, so, you know, it was speculation. I can't tell you anything specific if that's what you're asking.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: You can't tell me any specific as to why you speculated that.

utterances.speaker: BRADLEY
utterances.sentences: This was, however many years ago, I mean, I don't recall, but no, I don't.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: Did you have any reason to lie to me?

utterances.speaker: BRADLEY
utterances.sentences: I don't know if speculation is lying.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: But let me just -- show me where in this text says your speculation.

utterances.speaker: BRADLEY
utterances.sentences: You didn't ask me if I was speculating or guessing.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: I didn't ask you, but tell me if it says anywhere here --

utterances.speaker: BRADLEY
utterances.sentences: No(CROSSTALK)

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: -- that this is speculation.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: And you're welcome if you need to, to look at your texts. Is there anywhere in here that indicates that you didn't have knowledge of the relationship?

utterances.speaker: UNKNOWN
utterances.sentences: I'm going to object. The line of questioning your honor directed counsel to explore is where he got the knowledge. He's explored that. He said it's speculation and he didn't get it from any source other than his own speculation.

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: Sure. I think we're fleshing that out. And I think it's her right to have a little leeway on this if he's an adverse witness.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: Thank you, Judge. And Judge, these speaking objections are clearly coaching witness because he's regurgitating.

utterances.speaker: UNKNOWN
utterances.sentences: I object and take offense to that comment. I'm objecting based on the law and I'm making a record for the court. So, I take offense to that comment. It's not the case.

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: All right. Well, I think we can start with objection, the grounds and the rule number. And then if I need more, I'll ask.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: All right.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: Thank you. What did Nathan tell you about the relationship?

utterances.speaker: UNKNOWN
utterances.sentences: Objection. Hearsay.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: Nathan has testified. It's not hearsay.

utterances.speaker: UNKNOWN
utterances.sentences: It's still hearsay. It's an out of court statement being brought in for the truth of the matter asserted. So, hearsay.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: Judge.

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: Yeah, this would be for impeachment by contradiction, which would be an exception to the hearsay rule and admissible as substantive evidence. And the privilege issues are overruled.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: Thank you, Judge.

utterances.speaker: UNKNOWN
utterances.sentences: Well, I think he just overruled the privilege objection. But we don't know when he's talking about. So, we've already established that December 2018 was the day of the privilege. Sure.

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: And that's something I covered in the in-camera hearing. And based on what he told me in that in-camera hearing, I don't believe any statements to this effect were covered by privilege.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: And Judge, I just want for the record, because sometimes the record doesn't reflect where people are looking. And that when I ask a question, Mr. Bradley is looking at Mr. Wade and his lawyer to wait for them to object. And they're clearly interacting somehow in the court. So, I just want the record to reflect that because it wouldn't otherwise.

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: It's there now.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: A question was put to you, Mr. Bradley.

utterances.speaker: BRADLEY
utterances.sentences: Judge, one of my lawyers is standing, is sitting right in the back, A and(CROSSTALK)

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: (inaudible) You can look wherever you want.

utterances.speaker: BRADLEY
utterances.sentences: And I'd never looked at Mr. Wade or his attorneys. That's just not true (ph).

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: All right. Mr. Bradley, question was put to you.

utterances.speaker: BRADLEY
utterances.sentences: Repeat the question, please.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: Yes. So I showed you. Or  I asked you, I'm sorry. The question, the last question I asked you was, what did Nathan Wade tell you about the relationship?

utterances.speaker: UNKNOWN
utterances.sentences: Same objection, Your Honor.

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: And that's already been ruled upon. BRADLEY

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: One time?

utterances.speaker: BRADLEY
utterances.sentences: One time.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: You only had a conversation with him one time about the relationship?

utterances.speaker: UNKNOWN
utterances.sentences: Objection. Asked and answered.

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: No, I think that's a clarify for a thorough and sifting cross. Ms. Merchant.

utterances.speaker: BRADLEY
utterances.sentences: I do not recall any other time that he mentioned that they were in a relationship. No.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: So other than,  -- so you talked about this one time and you said you don't know when it was though, correct?

utterances.speaker: BRADLEY
utterances.sentences: That is correct.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: Was it before Mr. Wade, before you got the contract in Fulton County? Let's start with that.

utterances.speaker: BRADLEY
utterances.sentences: I do not recall.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: Okay. And how did it come up?

utterances.speaker: BRADLEY
utterances.sentences: Say again?

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: How did it come up?

utterances.speaker: BRADLEY
utterances.sentences: I do not recall how it came up. It was in the back. I know it was, I know where it occurred. In our offices in the back. I can't tell you what we were discussing prior to that.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: Okay. Did you receive an email from me on January 6th with a motion attached?

utterances.speaker: BRADLEY
utterances.sentences: I think I did. Yes. Yes. I know -- I received -- I don't know if the date is January 6th. Yes, I received it. Yes.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: So, you remember receiving that?

utterances.speaker: BRADLEY
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: -- Aand you reviewed it and then you, you and I spoke about it. You recall that?

utterances.speaker: BRADLEY
utterances.sentences: Did we speak over the phone or are you saying through a text?

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: That's what I'm asking you.
